Maurice John Vaughan Chicago Blues 73 Eighth Avenue, at 13th Street Manhattan Through tonight

Maurice John Vaughan called his debut album "Generic Blues" (Alligator-Independent), but he was being self-deprecating. In current Chicago blues, it's downright eccentric for Mr. Vaughan to play a hollow-body electric guitar, plucking the strings with his fingernails, and to include a trombonist in the four-piece band he has brought to Chicago Blues. Nor does Mr. Vaughan stick to tried-and-true lyrics. One of the toughest songs he sang on Tuesday night was "Computer Took My Job Away," a new version of the no-work blues carried by a modal vamp akin to John Lee Hooker

As with that song, Mr. Vaughan's way of updating the blues looks simultaneously back and into the present. With his small but supple voice, he gives phrases a rasp or a rhythmic twist to make them more cutting, or he doubles his vocal line with a guitar unison, although that can obscure the words. But his sparse, incisive guitar playing carries the songs. He plucks out wiry chords that echo rural blues, strums quick chords with a touch of big-band jazz, answers his own vocal lines with sly twangs, or plays terse, sighing single-note leads, all old-fashioned techniques but potent ones, abetted by a crisply efficient band.

On Tuesday night, Mr. Vaughan was a garrulous performer, joking more than his songs needed and tossing off slightly dated references to things like disco and break-dancing. But when he settled into the hard-luck story of a song like "The Big Bad Circle," the music stung.
